Hello Michael, Shawn here… I’ve had an interesting concept about rainbows ever since I was a kid, learning about geometry in school, which your video reminded me of. Fascinated by the mythological leprechaun’s pot of gold at the end of the rainbow, I tried to work out exactly ‘where’ the end of the rainbow actually was. So, if a rainbow is relative to the viewer and the light being refracted back towards the person’s eyes is coming from a circular shape, often bisected by the horizon, then the overall ‘shape’ this would create is a Cone. The ‘end’ of a cone is arguably it’s point or apex, which in this case is would be somewhere on your retinas. With this in mind, then the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow, is right there in your head!

Nothing amazing to tell about rainbows except for a true experience of mine I’ve always remembered from years ago. It was sometime in September 1985 and I was 18-years-old and one afternoon I was exploring by myself in the foothills of Moreno Valley, CA long before it was built up with subdivisions. I think my stepdads house was one of four or five houses up on the mountain at that time. I remember seeing a (bright?) rainbow very nearby in front of me and walked toward it but when I stopped close to the spot where I guessed the end of the rainbow should have been touching the ground it had completely disappeared. I was pretty sure I was close to being “inside” the rainbow. Of course there was no pot of gold (I did kind of looked around lol) but I remember being surprised that I really couldn’t see rainbow the closer I got to it (I did not know why that was back then) and it really wasn’t that far from me. I think I did try to walk back to where I initially saw it but it was gone. It was the only time in my life I just so happened to be that close to a rainbow.

I would like to tie two ideas together: Entropy (and the confusion of defining it just in terms of 'disorder', see video below) and Spontaneous Knotting of Agitated Strings.

If we replace the strings in a box with balls/marbles, thus instead of getting less possible states, like in the case of tied up strings, we get more possible states of marble-configurations, like in the definition of increasing entropy as the increasing number of microstates.

Q1: In other words: Would it make sense to equate the agitation of a box (full of strings/marbles) to the kinetic energy of microstates, and thus to a temperature?
Q2: Do you know of any further research about entropy of knots?
Q3: Maybe you will be inspired to do a new video, including both entropy & knots?

Q4: Am I just knotting my axions and agitating my marbles?! 8|

At 3:00, there's a third rainbow on the water surface. This isn't a reflection of a rainbow in the sky (you can tell this because it appears slightly to the side of the bow in the sky). This forms when light reflects off rain and then off the water and into your eyes. It's essentially the opposite of a reflection bow and is called a reflected rainbow.

Several other unique and uncommon bows are secondary reflection bows and reflected bows. These are just like the main or "primary" bows around a body of water but this time connected with the second bow. Another bow is a twinned rainbow. Nobody's sure how this forms. It appears as a usual primary bow but part way up, it splits into a second rainbow with the same brightness and colour order, reconnecting to the the primary at the same mirrored point on the other side of the bow.

Now for some bows that are always there but usually invisible are the 3rd and 4th order rainbows. Light doesn't stop reflect inside a raindrop after 2 times. In a first oder bow (the primary), we see a good chunk of the light that entered the drop. With a 2nd order bow, we see the light that escaped after a second reflection. In a 3rd order bow, the same thing happens. We see the escaped light that wasn't reflected after three reflections. But in the case of this reflection, the light leaves on the opposite side of the drop it entered. So the rainbow will be around the sun, instead of the shadow of your head. The significantly reduced brightness (because so much light has escaped as the primary and secondary bows), this bow is nearly impossible to see. The "zero order glow" caused by the sun (light that just passes through a drop without any reflection) enhances the difficulty of seeing a 3rd order bow. A 4th order bow is even fainter and also circles the sun.

Also possible are 5th and 6th etc order bows. Like I said, light will just reflecting until there's none left. 5th and 6th order bows again appear on the opposite side of the sun. But because each bow order seems to get larger, the 5th and 6th order bows will practically overlap each other and will be overpowered by the 1st and 2nd order bows. 7th and 8th order bows again are around the sun. 9th and 10th order bows are opposite, and so on. Sunlight, believe it or not, is only so bright, but higher orders can be made with exceptionally bright lasers.

One of the sites shown in the video is the go to site for info on optical phenomena. http://www.atoptics.co.uk/bows.htm

If you wonder why your desktop telephone receiver cable always twists up in knots the reason is this. Assume you're right handed (I'm left handed, by the way). The phone rings. You pick it up with your right hand. Someone asks you a question or gives you some details you need to write down. So you transfer the receiver to your left hand, keeping the earpiece/microphone facing your face, and pick up a pen in your right hand while you write stuff down. Then using your left hand, you put the phone down. What you have failed to notice is that in this operation, your receiver did a complete 360 degree rotation, twisting up the wire.  The reason the wire always gets more and more twisted is because the action doesn't vary and average out - you always pick up the phone with your major hand, transfer it to your minor hand and put it down using your minor hand, having added another twist to the cable.  The solution is, recognise that when you answer the phone, you're likely to be using your pen, so always pick up the phone with your "wrong" hand. That way, the phone never rotates and the cable never twists.

At 1:48 if anyone's confused about the diagram, I think I have it figured out. The two dotted lines parallel to each other is the rainbow, that arc, touching the ground both times. The many dots are rain drops in the air. "A" is sunlight, coming from behind you. The circle at the peak of the rainbow arc is where the refraction of light occurs. "E" is the light reaching your eyeballs, where you then perceive the image as a "Rainbow" And "M" is your shadow, which is at the center of the rainbow. (As Michael said in the video, a rainbow is not an arc, it's a circle, but since we are usually on the ground when we see a rainbow, it only appears to be an arc). The reason why a rainbow moves with you is because if there's always raindrops in the air wherever you move, and the sun is out, it will repeat this same process automatically, and immediately.

Yes, but only for some species. Color depends on the number of chromatic sensors in your retina, and humans only have 3. All colors we see are mixtures of red, blue, and green light. Other species like the mantis shrimp have over a dozen of these sensors, and can see colors humans cannot even imagine.

Yes.
Human's have 3 types of cones in our eyes: red, blue and green. This means we can see red blue and green and all colors derived from them (orange, purple, yellow, etc.) However, take an animal like the mantis shrimp, which has 16 different types of cones. This means it can see sixteen colors, 13 of which we can't see, and all colors derived from those (huyter, orbuvuvuv, tyuipogen, etc.)

Colors are an interesting subject. How we see is broken down on three colors, red, green and blue. Every color other than those is some sort of ratio of the two. Black being an absence of all color, and white being the presence of all color. Now, we are limited to the number of colors we see based on the number of rods and cones in our eyes. If we had more, we'd see more colors. There is an animal called the mantis shrimp, it has 16. The oatmeal has an article that talks about this a bit more.

Yes and no. I'm sure you are familiar with the visible spectrum. That's basically the range of wavelengths that the human eye can detect. Technically, anything outside of the visible spectrum-like infrared and ultraviolet-are undiscovered colors, but no one will ever know what these would look like. However, white light is white because it contains every color.  Moon rocks appear white because they reflect every color back to us, as does any other white object, just as a red object is not red because it produces light of only the red part of the spectrum, but because every other color is absorbed and only red light is reflected from the object into our eyes.  Without any colors, it would be black, which is either the absence of light/color, or the total absorption of the entire spectrum.

A rainbow it's a spectrum of the light (white light). The white light is made of 3 monochromatic light : Red, Green, Blue. Exemple a pixel, is made of 3 mini pixels. Each mini pixel is a rectangle that contains a color (RGB). By adjusting the intensity of each light in the pixel, you gain another light, like Blue and Green = Yellow (if there is 50% blue and 50% green). So rainbow is a REFRACTION of light, made by water drops that have the same role as a glass pyramid and divide light!

the point he was trying to make is what if everyone both saw and identified each color differently. For example, everyone sees grass as green. He poses the question, what if you saw the green grass as the color "green" but someone else saw the grass as the color "orange." The word for rainbow in other Germanic languages is similar to English: Regenbogen(German), regenboog(Dutch), regnbåge(Swedish), regnbogi(Icelandic).
But it Romance languages it seems to have something to do with light and/or its arc shape: arc-en-ciel(French)"arc in sky", arcobaleno(Italian)"arc flash", arco-íris(Portuguese), iris(Latin).
Some unusual translations I'd like to point out: ουράνιο τόξο(Greek) "uranium bow", arc de Sant and Martí(Catalan) "arc of St. Martin".

Theoretically, it's impossible to go faster than the speed of light. :D
However, as you approach the speed of light, images will be somewhat "crunched." Think about it this way: If you listen to a 3-minute-long song at a regular pace, it will sound natural (1/180 song per second). Then you speed it up and the sound gets crunched. Keep speeding up until you get asymptotically close to 1 song per second and the song will keep getting more and more crunched. It's *KIND OF* like that with light!

Wormholes don't let you travel faster than the speed of light. They are simply a bridge through the 4th dimension that allows 2 point in space to be joined. That being can only perceive forward/backward and up/down. so if we took the paper and joined the ends, the 2d being would not notice the bend in the paper, but would instead see an instant jump from one point on the paper to another. A wormhole does the same thing to the 3rd dimension.

There is only one state where the wires are not knotted. But there are countless ways they can be tangled up. So chances are, any given wire will be tangled.

As headphone wires get jostled around, they take on different positions, and tangled orientations are fairly probable, so they will occur fairly frequently. Then, once the wires reach one of those tangled orientations, it's virtually impossible for that one to untangle. The process then repeats, with the wire going through a bunch of random orientations, except with the already-formed knot staying fairly constant, so another knot forms, and the process repeats.

@tomhas10 By science: no. By sociology: yes. Science defines where 'red' and 'blue' exist by wavelengths. Since (barring color blindness, eye defects, etc.) we all perceive the wavelengths the same way Red will always look Red no matter who you are. However Red is a word, and thus a social construct. Technically if you went to a remote island and said the English word for those wavelengths is "Blue" then yes, their perception of color would be different.

Just google 'qualia' and you will understand

Interesting thing is that you cant actually see the color purple on a rainbow. Simply because your eyes are not able to see the color purple. Your eyes have 3 different "sensors" in them which catch different types of light, they are red, green, and blue, and your eyes can "see" anything in between those colors. Purple is beyond blue on the light spectrum, therefore, you cant actually see the color purple. instead your eyes have to mix green and blue in a certain way to create the color purple.

Interesting fact: Isaac Newton originally named the colours of the rainbow R.O.Y.G.B.V, leaving out indigo, making 6 colours. @vsauce actually the BOW in rainbow comes from the germanic word for arc (like the curve of a circle), not the decorative knot. Bow is a homonym (a single word with different meanings). Arguing about semantics on the internet... :P
